intro: Raphanus vesicarius, commonly known as the bladder mustard, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other mustard plants. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and features small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its leaves are lobed and often have a peppery taste, similar to other members of the mustard family. The plant is known for its inflated, saccate pods that contain the seeds, which are dispersed when the pods dry and split open.
